title: How Lakers handled uncertainty of China trip: 'We came out really good'
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: LeBron James had some critical words for Daryl Morey when he addressed the media on Monday night, calling the Rockets GM ' misinformed'. USA TODAY

LOS ANGELES — The Los Angeles Lakers traveled for 15 hours and believed they would spend their week this way. They would host a handful of clinics. They would play a pair of preseason games. They would expand their business portfolio. The throngs of Chinese fans would cheer their every move.

Instead, the Lakers’ week played out much differently. They landed in Shanghai a day after Rockets general manager Daryl Morey tweeted out support for the Hong Kong protestors. The Chinese government retaliated by pressuring the NBA to cancel community events. The Chinese’ state-run TV refused to broadcast the games, and various sponsors terminated their deals. The NBA canceled all of its media appearances. While NBA Commissioner Adam Silver apologized to China while defending Morey’s freedom of speech, the Lakers wondered if they would actually play. As Lakers guard Kentavious Caldwell-Pope admitted, “We thought they were going to be canceled.”

TERRIBLE WEEK FOR NBA: May open more eyes to price of doing business in China

Lakers guard Kentavious Caldwell-Pope (1) scores a basket against the Warriors during the second half at Staples Center. (Photo: Gary A. Vasquez, USA TODAY Sports)

So while the NBA sought to rectify its business relationship with China, the Lakers spent their time with each other.

“That trip really brought us together as a team,” Lakers center Dwight Howard said. “We had some really good moments. We will never forget those. Despite everything that happened, we came out really good.”

Howard maintained those top moments “will stay between us.” Yet, team accounts suggested the Lakers bonded in various ways.

They had team dinners. They played cards on the team plane and in the hotel. Even when construction workers tore down promotional ads for the Lakers’ preseason game against the Brooklyn Nets in Shanghai, the Lakers practiced as if they would still play. Once they did, the Lakers became increasingly confident they would return to the court for another pre-season game against Brooklyn in Shenzhen, China.

“I want to commend our guys for really blocking everything out and focusing on our process of trying to get better. We had a really productive trip,” Lakers coach Frank Vogel said. “This is one of the most locked-in groups I ever coached in terms of hanging on every word in film sessions, talking out coverages in practices and walk-throughs and throughout the game. They are really focused on trying to be great. That showed up on this trip.”

Granted, the Lakers still felt frustrated. James argued that Morey was “misinformed” on how his tweet could threaten both the players’ safety over there and their business deals. Silver also met with players on the Lakers and Nets to hear their concerns about being caught in the middle of an international incident. Silver offered a specific message.

“Just be us,” Caldwell-Pope said. “Stay within yourself and control what we can control.”

If only those were the challenges that awaited the Lakers. After the trip ended, they flew back to Los Angeles and landed around 5 a.m. PT because of weather delays. After having a day off to recover from jetlag, the Lakers then made their preseason debut against the Warriors at Staples Center.

The Warriors could sympathize to an extent. After winning two titles in three Finals appearances from 2015-17, the Warriors made a pre-season trip to China in 2017. But they did not play another game until five days after their trip ended.

“It’s worth it. I’m just surprised they scheduled this game less than 48 hours after returning,” Warriors coach Steve Kerr said. “It took us about a few weeks to get us over the jetlag.”

It might take that time for the Lakers, but they still had to play. Granted, the Lakers rested James, Danny Green, Avery Bradley and Rajon Rondo for that reason. The Lakers also sat Anthony Davis, whose MRI revealed a sprained right thumb and will be listed as day-to-day. And Kyle Kuzma missed his fourth exhibition game after just receiving clearance to complete non-contact drills while healing a stress reaction in his left foot.

Nonetheless, the Lakers still finished with a 104-98 win over a Warriors team that also sat Draymond Green and D’Angelo Russell. While Stephen Curry scored 17 points on 6-of-17 shooting in 21 minutes, the Lakers relied on a starting lineup featuring Zach Norvell Jr. (22 points), Howard (12 points, 13 rebounds, six assists), Caldwell-Pope (11 points), Alex Caruso, and Jared Dudley.

“It doesn’t matter who is in uniform. We’re trying to play to a standard and play a certain way,” Vogel said. “We’re trying to have an identity that we play harder than our opponent every night and we play more physical than our opponent every night.”
description: Here's an inside look at how the Lakers handled their week in China amid an international incident spurred by a tweet from Rockets GM Daryl Morey.
